blocks.text: By early October, we began connecting the index concept to existing platforms and tools students already use:

items: Exploring collective databases and how search features create feedback loops between system and viewer
Investigating the authorship of the reader and how feedback creates dialogue
Considering how to source and scavenge from individual databases to build collective ones
Thinking about sharing mechanisms: collective are.na boards, periodic scraping, feeding into larger systems
The complicated hierarchy of information organization
A small world with infinite possibilities expanding beyond borders

blocks.text: The role of the viewer and reader in creating meaning became increasingly important. We started recognizing that the research could take multiple forms for distribution, and that gathering and organization itself creates space for dialogue.
A critical refinement occurred when we recognized that applying formats to vague concepts was ineffective. Instead, we separated formats and qualities into distinct organizational systems:

items: Using affordances as one categorization system with format as secondary
Differentiating between process and final form
Using binary organization (linear/nonlinear) to define opposites
Treating affordances as ways to move between formats
Understanding that attributes maintain meaning across different formats
Recognizing that what we bring to the table is projects that blur these lines

blocks.text: Our framework shifted from black and white thinking to embracing blurry dichotomies. We stopped thinking of digital and physical as opposites and started thinking of them as interrelated systems. The attributes of a medium should have meaning in different ways across formats.
The affordances framework became increasingly sophisticated. We began:

items: Defining opposite affordances and what it means when an affordance is false
Clarifying affordances through their negation and counter-examples
Pulling examples from our database to illustrate each concept
Building a medium list from collected projects
Placing affordances in context of standard versus non-standard media use
Researching the history and parallel evolution of affordances

blocks.text: Crucial realization: tools are only as interesting as their contents. We started exploring why it matters for content to exist as a book versus a website versus a presentation, emphasizing containers and content relationships. Questions emerged: why does content need to be translated? How is it translated? What gets omitted or created to fit different kinds of containers? Can the research itself be the content?
This phase deepened our understanding of how historical forces shaped contemporary publishing:

items: The concept that the early internet was designed as an index, not a container
How translations from analogue to digital have evolved throughout internet history
The distinction between early internet practices and current Web 2 approaches
Our changing relationship to reading and how it changes our relationship to the web
The energy and constant maintenance required for websites versus the self-sustaining existence of books
The energy and flows of life constantly changing web content

blocks.text: Questions about reading shifted our approach: how our habits change, how relationships to indexing and searching have evolved, how our relationship to impermanence shapes publishing practices.
The next step became clear: we needed explicit definitions for the affordances and a working framework that could evolve with our research body.
As the framework solidified, new questions emerged that would shape later development:

items: The translation towards material forms
Whether all affordances must always be true for work to be interesting
Licensing conversations within ownability section
The difference between creator intent and user appropriation
How personal blogs changed our relationship to publishing
The centralization of the web through platforms post-Web 2
Distinguishing adaptability from updatability and reactivity
The role of feedback loops in publishing
RSS feeds and API structures for publishing

blocks.text: Key conceptual refinements: changing the framework versus the framework being reactive to users. We began eliminating sequentiality and exploring switching indexing systems between print and digital. The project itself could become the index/catalog. Being able to hide information anywhere and in anything.
The pedagogical structure took shape with concrete workshop plans. We moved from theory to practice:

items: First semester: students become experts in their own subject
Second semester: translating work for external audiences
Workshop series covering print form, publication possibilities, technology, and community engagement
Exploring how to deliver research through accessible, shareable means
Developing frameworks for showing students examples and inspiring expanded thinking
Non-book publications and experimental formats
Affordances as big chapters with descriptions, writings on histories, related readings, tutorials, precedents, and gesture experiments

blocks.text: The presentation itself needed to embody hybrid publishing principles. We organized affordances as the organizing structure. Key question emerged: is the workshop more of a show and tell, or a deep dive into the framework itself?
This phase emphasized that workshops should introduce but not fully develop the framework, leaving room for student interpretation and extension.

commits.subject: Initialize Astro project with starter files
commits.body: Added initial project structure for an Astro site, including configuration files, VS Code settings, .gitignore, starter README, favicon, and a minimal index page. Dependencies and project metadata are included in package.json and package-lock.json.

commits.subject: Add Google Sheets integration and UI components
commits.body: Introduces Google Sheets data fetching via opensheet.elk.sh, with environment configuration and error handling. Adds multiple Astro components (Card, FilterBar, Header, NetworkView, TabNav, TabSection), scripts for data/image fetching, config files, screenshots, and Tailwind CSS integration. Updates README with setup instructions and modifies Astro/Vite config for Tailwind support.

commits.subject: Update favicon and remove [tab] page
commits.body: Replaced the favicon.svg with a simplified circular icon and deleted the dynamic [tab].astro page from src/pages. The removal of [tab].astro suggests a change in routing or tab-based sheet display functionality.

commits.subject: Add Vercel adapter and analytics to Astro config
commits.body: Configured Astro to use the Vercel adapter with web analytics enabled and set output to static for deployment. Updated .gitignore to exclude .vercel directory. Added @astrojs/vercel and @vercel/analytics dependencies. No changes to application logic or UI.

commits.subject: Improve data file path resolution in dataLoader
commits.body: Updated loadTabData to check multiple possible paths for data files, increasing robustness when locating JSON sources. Error messages now list all attempted paths for easier debugging. Also removed unused Icon file and updated several screenshot images.

commits.subject: Improve image fetching and screenshot handling
commits.body: Enhances fetch-images.js to skip screenshots in CI/Vercel environments, preserve and update existing images, and provide clearer logging. Also improves robustness by loading existing images.json and handling screenshot failures gracefully. Minor formatting updates in astro.config.mjs and dataLoader.js.

commits.subject: Add EmbedBrowser component and enhance UI
commits.body: Introduces the EmbedBrowser component for in-app link previews with minimize, fullscreen, and taskbar features. Improves NetworkView with header and footer, refines force simulation for smoother layout, and updates global styles for new UI elements. Also adds a footer to the main page and ensures scroll locking in network view.

commits.subject: Add menu component and improve embed browser UX
commits.body: Introduces a new Menu component for navigation and updates the layout to include top controls. Refines the EmbedBrowser overlay and modal transitions, improves external link handling, and adjusts NetworkView zoom extents. Updates global styles for top controls and refactors view toggle logic for better user experience.

commits.subject: Add mermaid integration and new markdown pages
commits.body: Integrated astro-mermaid for diagram support and configured custom theme variables. Added new markdown pages (about, contact), a base layout, and markdown styles. Removed TabNav component and updated several components and global styles to support new features.

commits.subject: Add local screenshots and update image references
commits.body: Downloaded and added local screenshot files for referenced projects and tools. Updated image URLs in images.json to use local paths. Improved fetch-images.js to download images and handle redirects, and updated UI components and styles for better navigation and changelog support. Added changelog.md page documenting project development.

commits.subject: Add affordances framework and restructure content
commits.body: Introduces six affordance markdown files and supporting layouts, establishing a new content architecture for the publication. Removes legacy config files, adds Astro content collection config, and updates project scripts for changelog generation. Refactors styles and components for modularity, updates README with new structure and setup, and replaces changelog and contact pages with new Astro pages.

commits.subject: Update changelog and revise about page content
commits.body: Added a new changelog entry for the affordances framework and content restructuring. Revised the about page to detail the project's two-phase approach, clarifying materials, index, and prototypes for each phase and emphasizing the project's framework for hybrid publishing practices.
